page.title: 12GEOLOGY ON ALSTON MOOR
page.content: The landscape of Alston Moor consists of an alternating sequence of shale, sandstone, thin coal (not always present) and limestone. The sandstone has been much quarried in the past for local buildings and is still quarried in Nenthead today. Some of the coal seams are still being worked in shallow drift mines along the valley sides. Igneous intrusions in the form of a connected series of dolerite sills (the Whin Sill) were later intruded into the sedimentary rocks, although generally lying below the surface there are two outcrops at Tynehead and Cash Force. Dykes associated with these intrusions traverse the area in great numbers and many are mineralised. Valuable ores of lead and zinc along with smaller quantities of silver, copper and iron have all been extracted in the past.
